content.question: Regarding the load factor, an aircraft's maximum allowable load factor is determined by the manufacturer. For a particular aircraft, the maximum load limit with flaps extended is half of the load factor in the clean configuration. Which of the following options completes the statement correctly? In level and unaccelerated flight...

options.A: the difference between maximum load limit for flaps extended and clean wing is necessary as structural strength of the wing is lower with flaps extended.
options.B: the load factor with flaps extended will be higher than the load factor in the clean configuration.
options.C: the margin between actual load factor and maximum load factor decreases with increased bank angle.
options.D: the load factor at which structural damage occurs can never be more than +2.0G when flaps are extended.

key_points: Let's go through each answer: "In level and unaccelerated flight
the difference between maximum load limit for flaps extended and clean wing is necessary as structural strength of the wing is lower with flaps extended
" This is saying that the wing is weaker when flaps are extended
learning.explanation: Let's go through each answer: "In level and unaccelerated flight. the difference between maximum load limit for flaps extended and clean wing is necessary as structural strength of the wing is lower with flaps extended." This is saying that the wing is weaker when flaps are extended. This is not correct, as the wing structure does not rely of the flaps. What actually causes the lower maximum load factor with flaps extended is the flap mechanism. With flaps extended, the higher the load factor, the more force is travelling through the mechanism which locks the flaps down, which are moving parts, so not as strong as the wing itself. "In level and unaccelerated flight. the load factor with flaps extended will be higher than the load factor in the clean configuration." The load factor is simply lift/weight, and in straight and level flight, the lift will always equal the weight, therefore the load factor is 1, whether the flaps are up and down. It has not specified straight flight, but the same would be true in a turn of a particular bank angle; load factor is the same, with or without flaps. "In level and unaccelerated flight. the margin between current load factor and maximum load factor decreases with increased bank angle." Correct. In a level turn, the aircraft's wings have to produce a higher lift force, as the lift force is no longer straight upwards, but is instead pointing into the direction of turn somewhat. The steeper the bank angle, the greater the lift force has to be (to remain level), which means that the actual load factor has to increase. As the maximum load factor is a fixed value, the margin between actual and maximum decreases with increased bank angle. "In level and unaccelerated flight. the load factor at which structural damage occurs can never be more than +2.0G when flaps are extended." We had no feedback for this option, so made this up to fill in the gap. It is incorrect because flaps can be made as strong as you like. They could manage up to +15G if the manufacturer wants to. There are minimum values to their strength though, defined in the certification specifications.

Any and all of those will have an impact on the smoothness of the airframe
As we know, laminar airflow produces less drag than turbulent airflow, therefore if possible, we would like to have as much possible laminar airflow around the body of the aircraft as possible
learning.explanation: In basic terms, ageing means an increase in scratches, dirt, dents and other such ‘wear’. Any and all of those will have an impact on the smoothness of the airframe. As we know, laminar airflow produces less drag than turbulent airflow, therefore if possible, we would like to have as much possible laminar airflow around the body of the aircraft as possible. Scratches, dents and dirt lead to an earlier transition point and therefore a larger area of the aircraft surface will be covered with turbulent airflow, meaning more drag. Ageing will therefore increase the skin friction drag.

content.question: The safe life of an aircraft structure is defined as the minimum life during which…

options.A: the structure eliminates extra structural members by spreading the loading of a particular structure over a larger area.
options.B: the structure will never fail during a declared time period or number of cycles.
options.C: a failure of a particular part is compensated for by an alternative load path provided by an adjacent part that is able to carry the loads for a limited period.
options.D: it is known that no catastrophic damage will occur.

key_points: For this question you need to know the difference between Safe-Life and Fail-Safe design
Safe-Life: This is de minimum life during which it is known that no catastrophic damage should occur
The life of such a structure can be defined in different ways, cycles, flight hours, pressurization events or calendar time
learning.explanation: For this question you need to know the difference between Safe-Life and Fail-Safe design. Safe-Life: This is de minimum life during which it is known that no catastrophic damage should occur. The life of such a structure can be defined in different ways, cycles, flight hours, pressurization events or calendar time. After this interval has been reached the structure should be replaced, inspected or overhauled per manufacturers recommendations. Fail-safe: When a structure fails there is alternative load-path provided by an adjacent part which is able to take over the loads for a limited amount of time. This normally should be enough time until the next periodic inspection where the damage should be identified and the damaged part replaced. The answer: “the structure will never fail during a declared time period or number of cycles” is incorrect because a structure might fail during the declared time but it should not bring catastrophic damage.

During a pre-flight inspection, what could indicate stress damage on an aircraft?
1. Wrinkled or stretched skin
2. Loose or missing screws in the fairings
3. Hydraulic leak in the landing gear (bypassing of the piston seal)
4. Restriction in a flight control

options.B: 1 and 4.

key_points: Generally speaking every component of an airframe is designed to be thin to reduce the overall weight of the aircraft but, at the same time, every piece, including the “outer skin”, is required to bear load along with the longerons and frames (the main load-bearing components of the airplane structure)
This load can be of three types: compression, tension and shear load
When the thin skin panels of the aircraft are under stress, they may buckle and when the light comes from the right angle, such buckling can be apparent as “wrinkles” during the pre-flight inspection
learning.explanation: Generally speaking every component of an airframe is designed to be thin to reduce the overall weight of the aircraft but, at the same time, every piece, including the “outer skin”, is required to bear load along with the longerons and frames (the main load-bearing components of the airplane structure). This load can be of three types: compression, tension and shear load. When the thin skin panels of the aircraft are under stress, they may buckle and when the light comes from the right angle, such buckling can be apparent as “wrinkles” during the pre-flight inspection. Needless to say, the age of the airframes and metal fatigue may affect the amount and distribution of the aircraft’s “wrinkles” or “stretched” skin. During a pre-flight inspection, control surfaces are carefully inspected to ensure these are free and in correct motion. Physical restriction on the surface can be caused by damage or icing and will be detected as a change in the upper and/or lower limits to new, non-equal values.

content.question: Which statement describes how forces act on the airframe during manoeuvring in flight?

options.A: Both strain and stress increase as the forces increase.
options.B: When the lift exactly opposes the weight, strain is NOT increased due to stress.
options.C: Both stress and strain decrease as the forces increase.
options.D: The strain increases and stress decreases as the forces increase.

key_points: An aircraft is constantly subject to various forces; tension, compression, torsion and shearing forces are all occurring in an aircraft in varying amounts
Any of these forces can be described in terms of stress and strain
Stress is the measure of force applied (per unit of cross-sectional area) whereas strain is the measure of deformation, usually as a proportion of the original size of the component
learning.explanation: An aircraft is constantly subject to various forces; tension, compression, torsion and shearing forces are all occurring in an aircraft in varying amounts. Any of these forces can be described in terms of stress and strain. Stress is the measure of force applied (per unit of cross-sectional area) whereas strain is the measure of deformation, usually as a proportion of the original size of the component. They are present on almost every item in some way, and are present in a multitude of different ways on an aircraft at all times. When an aircraft manoeuvres, for instance by entering a turn, the load factor on the wings increases, as the wings are now required to produce more lift than before. This leads to a change in the stress (and therefore strain) on the aircraft, in particular for this scenario, an increased load on the wing spars and roots, which cause a flex in the wing, demonstrating the extra strain present. Therefore, for this question, any force increase will increase the stress on the aircraft (as stress is force per unit area) and any stress will increase strain (the aircraft's deformation due to the stress).

One important step is to check the maintenance documents. These documents are like the airplane's history books. They keep track of all the maintenance work that has been done on the plane, including any repairs or inspections related to its structure. By looking at these documents, the pilot can see if everything has been properly taken care of according to the rules and guidelines. One of these documents is the aircraft's tech log, which is used to record the operational status of an aircraft. It serves as a detailed record of the aircraft's flights, maintenance activities, and any reported issues or discrepancies. Additionally, relying solely on verbal communication may not offer the comprehensive documentation and verification needed to ensure the integrity of the aircraft's structure. "Review the flight crew's credentials" Incorrect: Reviewing the flight crew's credentials is essential for ensuring that qualified personnel are operating the aircraft. However, it doesn't directly address the structural integrity of the aircraft.

content.question: When are stress and strain zero in an aircraft structure?

options.A: When the aircraft has zero flight hours.
options.B: When parked, with the engines not running.
options.C: When flying with a 1G load factor.
options.D: Never, stress and strain are always present.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.01.02.01.01: Explain how stress and strain are always present in an aircraft structure both when parked and during manoeuvring. Remark: Stress is the internal force per unit area inside a structural part as a result of external loads. Strain is the deformation caused by the action of stress on a material. An aircraft is constantly subject to various forces; tension, compression, torsion and shearing forces are all occurring in an aircraft in varying amounts. For instance, when stationary on the ground, the wing is heavy, and is being pulled down due to gravity, wanting to droop downwards away from the fixed wing root. This means that the top surface of the wing will be under tension, as it is trying to be stretched, but the bottom surface would be under compression, as it is being squashed. Also, The weight of the whole aircraft is being opposed by reaction forces that travel through the landing gear and all the structurally load bearing components of the structure. These are amongst the many forces acting on a stationary aeroplane. The forces are very different when flying in straight and level (1 G) flight, where, for instance, the wings are suspending the heavy fuselage due to their ability to create lift. In this case the wings are flexing upwards away from the wing root, as can be seen very clearly on newer aircraft such as the B787 and A350. In this scenario, the upper surface of the wing is being squashed, so is under compression, where the bottom surface of the wing is under tension. The rest of the aircraft also sustains new forces, such as that of pressurisation on the pressure hull. The forces change again during manoeuvres, taxi, take-off and landing. Any of these forces can be described in terms of stress and strain. Stress is the measure of force applied (per unit of cross-sectional area) whereas strain is the measure of deformation, usually as a proportion of the original size of the component. They are present on almost every item in some way, and are present in a multitude of different ways on an aircraft at all times.

key_points: Fatigue is a term which is used for materials which have to endure cyclic loads
This is where a structure experiences reversal of loading and will fail at a load of less force than it would for a steadily applied load

So this can appear on the fuselage because of the pressurisation cycle or on the wings and isn’t something which can be detected by any infrared sensor or other kind of system on the aircraft and will need to be done by a mechanic visually during scheduled maintenance
learning.explanation: Fatigue is a term which is used for materials which have to endure cyclic loads. This is where a structure experiences reversal of loading and will fail at a load of less force than it would for a steadily applied load. So this can appear on the fuselage because of the pressurisation cycle or on the wings and isn’t something which can be detected by any infrared sensor or other kind of system on the aircraft and will need to be done by a mechanic visually during scheduled maintenance. Health and Usage Monitoring Systems (HUMS) are designed to automatically monitor the health of mechanical components in a helicopter, as well as usage of the airframe and its dynamic components. So this has nothing to do with fatigue. Magnetic chip detectors are usually placed in the engine’s oil system as chips of metal can indicate an impending engine failure.

The performance of atmospherically exposed metals depends on five main factors: temperature, humidity, rainfall, Sulphur dioxide (pollution) concentration in the air, and air salinity. Temperature - an increase in temperature will generally cause an increase in the corrosion rate. A rule of thumb is that temperature increases of 10°C will double the corrosion rate. Humidity - has a direct effect on the rate of corrosion of metals. The higher the humidity, the higher the rate of corrosion. Rainfall - leads to an increased humidity - therefore, higher rate of corrosion. Sulphur Dioxide (pollution) - is known to cause considerable damage to materials. These pollutants can accelerate the rate of corrosion. Air Salinity - an increase in air salinity levels will generally cause an increase in the corrosion rate. Over the ocean at low altitude, the air will have a high salinity, leading to a build up of salt on the airframe, which, when mixed with water, can lead to fast corrosion of metal. The best way to deal with the operator's problem would be to wash the aircraft as often as they can, and very thoroughly, to clear off the salt and replace it with clean water that corrodes metal much less. The correct option (rightly) mentions the engine too, as this can build up salt deposits in just the same way as the airframe does, and corrosion is obviously much more dangerous when there are pieces of metal spinning at 50 000 RPM. Whilst the best long term fix for this issue would be changing the fleet of aircraft to ones more suited to the task, this would be immensely expensive, and maybe not even possible. Yes, if you were doing some light aircraft intelligence, surveillance or reconnaissance work, then you could change to a fleet of composite aircraft to remove the risk of corrosion, which is a huge investment, but there are aircraft available for that type of operation, so is possible. However, if you were doing oil spill response or something which requires large jets, they are all metal and all subject to corrosion (except some of the newer jets like B787 and A350), so this answer is not feasible.

As stated in the Learning Objective above, there are three types of load, but they are not completely mutually exclusive. Static loads are loads that do not change in size, position or direction. These could be loads such as the weight of the aircraft through the wheels when parked, or the tension on the upper skin of the wing when on the ground. They are quite easy to account for. Dynamic loads are loads that do change in size, position or direction. They must be accounted for more heavily by engineers, as a constantly changing load can cause more fatigue or early failure if not expected. There are countless dynamic loads on an aircraft, taxiing loads, the engine pylons, the bending of the wing spar in turbulent flight, the control surfaces during manoeuvring, etc. Cyclic loads are a special type of the aforementioned loads. They are loads which have expected cycles, the main one being the pressurisation cycle of the aircraft. It is a static load when non-pressurised and when fully pressurised, but dynamic as it changes. The cyclical nature does mean that engineers can build it to last, and monitor it's progress also, giving an aircraft a number of available pressurisation cycles, which can dictate its lifespan. This question simply wants you to know that there are constantly loads of all types occuring on an aircraft at all times. static loads also occur whilst in flight, and dynamic loads occur on the ground, even when parked (wind, boarding, etc.), so the two statements are both incorrect.

The limit load (usually known as limit load factor) of an aeroplane is the maximum load it is expected to experience during flight operations. The aircraft must be capable of withstanding 150% of this "limit load" before failure occurs (which is the "ultimate load"). CS-25 aircraft, for instance, have a limit load factor of 2.5G at the minimum, meaning that they must be tested to 3.75G (150% of 2.5) without failure. learning.explanation: Corrosion is where two substances begin to change the composition of each other when mixed. learning.explanation: Structural design concepts are developed to ensure safe operation of aircraft components. The Safe-life philosophy indicates that a component in the aircraft has a given time period or life cycle that it should withstand without any failure. The life of such a structure can be defined in different ways, cycles, flight hours, pressurization events or calendar time. The Safe-life philosophy requires parts to be replaced at the end of their specified life, regardless of their condition. A Fail-safe structural element is designed so that the part distributes the load in a way that it goes through multiple load paths. This means that in the case of a crack in the structural element appearing, the rest of the structure is still able to withstand the prescribed loads for a limited amount of time until the crack is detected by maintenance and the element replaced. This principle is called redundancy.

content.question: Which of the following areas of the aircraft are prone to stress, and should the pilot pay close attention to during the pre-flight inspection?

options.B: Wing root fairings.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.01.02.01.03: Describe the areas typically prone to stress that should be given particular attention during a pre-flight inspection, and highlight the limited visual cues of any deformation that may be evident. This question and the available options are quite ridiculous. We believe that the wing root fairings are probably most correct, as they cover the wing root, the highest stress point on the aircraft, and any deformation (due to high stress) would cause cracking, which may be visible on the fairing. However, it appears that most authorities are considering the "wing root fairings" to be incorrect (Spain and Poland confirmed). We think the next best answer is the "aft pressure bulkhead", but that is unconfirmed. Please send us any further exam feedback you have and let us know which authority you sat with, thank you! We obviously agree that a thorough inspection of the tail skid is important, as this is where evidence of tailstrikes would show, but we find the wording a little incongruous. We cannot inspect the aft pressure bulkhead itself - which is the area prone to stress due to pressurisation - as it is inside the aircraft skin, and the tail-skid itself is not naturally prone to stress (other than damage from tailstrikes). Furthermore, if the aft pressure bulkhead is considered correct, surely the forward pressure bulkhead must be correct also, in the fact that it cannot be inspected directly (as it is internal), but the outer skin can be inspected and is also prone to damage (birdstrikes). Therefore, we find it very unclear what the examiner is really asking here. Realistically, the exam wording makes quite a big difference to the question also. If the question does not include "prone to stress", then the argument is very different, as well as if different options are present. Neither the question nor the options have been verified as having the exact wording. We therefore need as much feedback for this one as we can get, thank you! content.question: Windshield heating of a transport aeroplane is…

options.B: only used when hot-air demisting is insufficient.
options.C: essential to improve the strength and flexibility of the cockpit windows.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.04.01.10: Explain the function of window heating for structural purposes. The flight deck windshield is made of many different layers of materials, mostly plastics such as acrylic and vinyl, as well as some layers of toughened glass, to give it favourable properties such as high strength, good flexibility (for impact resistance) and a hard wearing outer coating, with good rain resistance. They also contain heating elements which have a couple of different jobs, their main job being to keep the plastics in a slightly softer state, where they are flexible enough to absorb and deflect impacts from objects like birds at very high speeds. If the heating was not present, then the windshield would become very brittle in the extreme cold of the upper airways and could break more easily upon impact. The secondary jobs of the heated windshield are de-fogging and de-icing, which are important in their own right, but are certainly a secondary consideration to the impact resistance.

content.question: Which of the following can help to reduce the vertical bending moments experienced by an aircraft wing during flight?

options.B: Increasing the number of passenger seats.
options.C: Reducing the size of the vertical stabiliser.
options.D: Increasing the size of the windows around the wings.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.03.03.04: Explain the following countermeasures used to achieve stress relief and reduce resonance: chord-wise and span-wise position of masses (e.g. engines, fuel, balance masses for wing and control balance masses); torsional stiffness; bending flexibility; fuel-balancing procedures during flight (automatic or applied by the pilot). When an aircraft is in flight, the weight of the whole aircraft is being suspended by the wings. This means that the forces on the wings are enormous, and the wing roots in particular take a massive strain. These forces result in the wings flexing upwards during flight, as the outer sections of the wings are exerting force all through the wing spar, which causes it to bend slightly upwards. We do not want extremely stiff wings, as they would be brittle, and more likely to break. We are therefore happy for wings to flex, and it has become more common in newer aircraft to allow a lot of flex. Of course, there is only so much flex a material can handle though, so we can counteract it by changing an aircraft's design and how we operate it. By putting fuel in the wings, we weigh them down, to fight off some of the upwards flex from the lift. Most aircraft have their wings as their main tanks, so there is always some fuel in the wings to make this happen. This is also one of the reasons that many aircraft use up the fuel in their centre (fuselage) tanks first when possible, leaving the wing tanks full until the aircraft is a little lighter, and has less wing flex.

Which of these statements about composite and metal structures are correct or incorrect?

options.B: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

key_points: MATERIALS Modern aircraft are constructed mainly of aluminium and its alloys with smaller amounts of steel and titanium for the major structural components with composite materials used extensively for more lightly loaded structures
However many of the latest aircraft make use of modern composites for the empennage, cabin floor panels, flying control surfaces, engine cowlings and fairings
Each material is chosen for its particular properties with regard to fatigue strength, wear resistance, strength to weight ratio, fire resistance etc
learning.explanation: MATERIALS Modern aircraft are constructed mainly of aluminium and its alloys with smaller amounts of steel and titanium for the major structural components with composite materials used extensively for more lightly loaded structures. However many of the latest aircraft make use of modern composites for the empennage, cabin floor panels, flying control surfaces, engine cowlings and fairings. Each material is chosen for its particular properties with regard to fatigue strength, wear resistance, strength to weight ratio, fire resistance etc. COMPOSITE MATERIALS Composite materials are made of at least two elements to produce a material with properties that are different to those of the original elements. Nearly all composites consist of a bulk material, this is called the matrix and some form of reinforcement. This reinforcement is used mainly to increase the strength and stiffness of the matrix and is usually in a fibre form. ADVANTAGES OF COMPOSITE MATERIALS - The ability to arrange the fibres to obtain directional properties consistent with the load - The ability to make complex shapes, since the material is not homogeneous - Weight savings - Resistance to corrosion - High specific strength - High specific stiffness DISADVANTAGES OF COMPOSITE MATERIALS - They are quickly eroded by hail, sand, etc, so leading edges must be sheathed. - They are difficult to repair. - They can absorb moisture if the material is not correctly sealed. When comparing composite and metal structures, composite are: - Lighter: Composites can be up to 70 percent lighter than metal. - High strength-to-weight ratio: composites have a high strength-to-weight ratio. Carbon fiber weighs about 25% as much as steel and 70% as much as aluminum, and is much stronger and stiffer than both materials per weight. Therefore, statement II is incorrect. - Stronger: When increasing the strength of metal, it must be equally strong in all directions thickening the material and causing an increase in weight. Composites however can be engineered and designed to be strong in a specific direction while keeping it lightweight. Therefore, statement I is incorrect. - Corrosion Resistant: Composites resist weather damage and other harsh chemicals that would typically damage metal. - Nonconductive: Unlike steel, composites are nonconductive.

learning.explanation: Most modern aircraft fuselages are usually of semimonocoque construction. The semimonocoque design overcomes the strength-to-weight problem of monocoque construction. The outside skin gives the fuselage its aerodynamic shape and can support a major portion of the flight loads. Longerons hold the bulkheads and formers. The longerons are supplemented by other longitudinal members known as stringers. Stringers stiffen the skin and assist the sheet materials to carry loads along their length. Stringers and longerons prevent tension and compression stresses from bending the fuselage. The vertical/lateral structural members are referred to as bulkheads, rings and formers (frames) and determine the cross-sectional shape of the fuselage. The bulkheads, rings and formers hold the stringers. All of these join together to form a rigid fuselage framework. Note: Stringers, floor beams and longerons are longitudinal components.

They also contain heating elements which have a couple of different jobs, their main job being to keep the plastics (vinyl and acrylic) in a slightly softer state, where they are flexible enough to absorb and deflect impacts from objects like birds at very high speeds. Glass is not quite as good for aircraft windshields, and even though there may be some form of glass within the many layers, the heating would not affect its properties to the same scale as the vinyl, and the glass has different properties anyway. If the heating was not present, then the windshield would become very brittle in the extreme cold of the upper airways and could break more easily upon impact. The secondary jobs of the heated windshield are de-fogging and de-icing, which are important in their own right, but are certainly a secondary consideration to the impact resistance.

content.question: On most transport aircraft, flight deck windows are heated to…

options.B: Enhance visibility during bird strikes.

key_points: Flight deck windows installed in pressurized aircraft must endure the stresses of pressurization as well as potential impacts from bird strikes
These windows are crafted using toughened glass panels sandwiching a transparent vinyl interlayer
In the event of a bird strike, the vinyl interlayer can absorb and disperse the shock by stretching and deforming, thereby preventing the glass from shattering
learning.explanation: Flight deck windows installed in pressurized aircraft must endure the stresses of pressurization as well as potential impacts from bird strikes. These windows are crafted using toughened glass panels sandwiching a transparent vinyl interlayer. In the event of a bird strike, the vinyl interlayer can absorb and disperse the shock by stretching and deforming, thereby preventing the glass from shattering. To secure the windows, they are fastened to the frame using bolts that pass through the edges of the windscreen. To counter ice formation and enhance bird strike resistance, an electrically conducting coating is applied to the inner surface of the outer glass panel, providing the window with heating capabilities. This heating system helps maintain a clear window surface and ensures enhanced durability in the face of bird strikes.

content.question: How can upwards wing flex be avoided?

options.B: Increase take off weight.
options.C: Place the engines closer to the fuselage.
options.D: Keep fuel in the wing tanks as long as possible.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.03.03.04: Explain the following countermeasures used to achieve stress relief and reduce resonance: chord-wise and span-wise position of masses (e.g. engines, fuel, balance masses for wing and control balance masses); torsional stiffness; bending flexibility; fuel-balancing procedures during flight (automatic or applied by the pilot). When an aircraft is in flight, the weight of the whole aircraft is being suspended by the wings. This means that the forces on the wings are enormous, and the wing roots in particular take a massive strain. These forces result in the wings flexing upwards during flight, as the outer sections of the wings are exerting force all through the wing spar, which causes it to bend slightly upwards. We do not want extremely stiff wings, as they would be brittle, and more likely to break. We are therefore happy for wings to flex, and it has become more common in newer aircraft to allow a lot of flex. Of course, there is only so much flex a material can handle though, so we can counteract it by changing an aircraft's design and how we operate it. By putting fuel in the wings, we weigh them down, to fight off some of the upwards flex from the lift. Most aircraft have their wings as their main tanks, so there is always some fuel in the wings to make this happen. This is also one of the reasons that many aircraft use up the fuel in their centre (fuselage) tanks first when possible, leaving the wing tanks full until the aircraft is a little lighter, and has less wing flex.

content.question: In some aircraft flight decks, devices are fitted that consist of 2 white balls and a red ball. These are used to find the correct eye-reference position, helping to...

options.B: minimise eye movement.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.04.01.12: Explain the need for an eye-reference position. Not all aircraft have them, but eye-reference guides are very useful for pilots to be able to set up their seating position correctly. Every flight deck is designed in a way that the pilot should be able to see and interact with every vital piece of information/device without having to move their head. They will obviously need to move their eyes, and swivel their head sometimes, but setting their eye position is a great way to make sure that the pilot can see everything that they need to see, including out of the window. To use the red and white balls, the pilot simply sits so the red ball completely obscures the view of the white ball behind (or vice-versa on some aircraft, depending on colours), and their eye position should be correct.

content.question: Which of the following statements correctly details the reasons and implications for some aircraft designs mounting the horizontal stabiliser on top of the fin (T-tail)?

options.A: It increases manoeuvrability and responsiveness, it is a simpler design and therefore saves on production cost, but it is harder to inspect after de-icing, and requires more ground handling equipment.
options.B: It has a smoother airflow and therefore more predictable flight characteristics, but requires a stronger, heavier fin, and is susceptible to loss of effectiveness at high angles of attack.
options.C: It allows for greater ground clearance when taxiing, it is a simpler design, therefore saving production cost, but it is harder to inspect after de-icing, and requires more ground handling equipment.
options.D: It has a smoother airflow, therefore more predictable flight characteristics, it has a wider operating range in pitch, but requires a stronger, therefore heavier fin.

key_points: Note: this does delve into priciples of flight a little, but is still within AGK enough to be acceptable
Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Note: this does delve into priciples of flight a little, but is still within AGK enough to be acceptable. Learning Objective 021.02.03.01.01: Describe the following types of design and explain their advantages and disadvantages: high-mounted wing; low-mounted wing; low- or mid-set tailplane; T-tail. There are two main places that an aircraft designer can mount a horizontal stabiliser at the rear of an aircraft. One place is "low mounted", at the base of the tail fin, and the other place is at the top of the fin, a "T-tail" due to its shape looking like the letter "T". The low-mounted position tends to be more common on large civilian transport aircraft these days, but both mounting locations have their own positive and negative factors. We will now talk about T-tail in comparison to low-mounted. T-tails have the horizontal stabiliser up and away from the turbulence created by the wing (during normal flight), which means the airflow over the tailplane is smoother. As the tailplane is therefore less affected by the downwash from the main wing, we can refer to this mounting position as "stabilising" (some questions in PoF ask about this). T-tails also make the fin and rudder more effective, as they act as a winglet for the fin and rudder, so a smaller rudder is required. However, all the forces produced by the horizontal stabiliser and the elevators must travel through the fin, meaning that the fin must be made much stronger (and therefore heavier) than if the stabiliser was mounted on the fuselage at the bottom. Also, a more practical consideration is that inspection is more difficult, especially when it comes to icing/de-icing. The final consideration for a T-tail is probably the most well known. The horizontal stabiliser may be out of the way of the turbulence from the wing during normal flight, but at high angles of attack, the tailplane will now be within the stalled region behind the wing, leading to a stall where no elevator control is possible, called a deep-stall. Deep-stalls can sometimes be unrecoverable. So let's go through the options. "It increases manoeuvrability and responsiveness, it is a simpler design and therefore saves on production cost, but it is harder to inspect after de-icing, and requires more ground handling equipment." Incorrect. It has a stabilising effect on the aircraft, so decreases manoeuvrability. It is not simpler to design, requiring a very strong fin. It is obviously harder to inspect though, that bit is correct. "It has a smoother airflow and therefore more predictable flight characteristics, but requires a stronger, heavier fin, and is susceptible to loss of effectiveness at high angles of attack." Correct, as mentioned above, the smoother airflow is correct, the stronger, heavier fin is also correct, and the last section which refers to a deep-stall at high angles of attack is correct as well for a T-tail. "It allows for greater ground clearance when taxiing, it is a simpler design, therefore saving production cost, but it is harder to inspect after de-icing, and requires more ground handling equipment." Incorrect. Ground clearance is debatable, as an aircraft's wings are usually more of a concern for that. It is not simpler to design, as it requires a stronger fin. The last section about de-icing is correct, though. "It has a smoother airflow, therefore more predictable flight characteristics, it has a wider operating range in pitch, but requires a stronger, therefore heavier fin." Incorrect. Smoother airflow, yes; but it certainly does not have a wider operating range in pitch, as it suffers from deep-stalls, becoming useless at high angles of attack. It does require a heavier fin though.

content.question: When in a gust a wing bends downwards, aileron flutter might occur if the aileron deflects:

options.A: downwards, because the location of the aileron centre of gravity lies behind the hinge line.
options.B: upwards, because the location of the aileron centre of gravity lies in front of the hinge line.
options.C: downwards, because the location of the aileron centre of gravity lies in front of the hinge line.
options.D: upwards, because the location of the aileron centre of gravity lies behind the hinge line.

key_points: FLUTTER AND RESONANCE Flutter is an uncontrolled oscillation that can occur on fixed surfaces, such as the wing or on control surfaces such as the ailerons or elevators
Flutter is caused by the interaction of aerodynamic forces, inertia forces and the elastic properties of the surface or structure and can lead to the catastrophic failure of the structure
An aircraft that is in the cruise will be supported by its wings and they will be bent upwards
learning.explanation: FLUTTER AND RESONANCE Flutter is an uncontrolled oscillation that can occur on fixed surfaces, such as the wing or on control surfaces such as the ailerons or elevators. Flutter is caused by the interaction of aerodynamic forces, inertia forces and the elastic properties of the surface or structure and can lead to the catastrophic failure of the structure. An aircraft that is in the cruise will be supported by its wings and they will be bent upwards. If the aircraft is subjected to a gust it will shake up and down with the wings flapping at a certain frequency. If the vibration is similar to that of the structure of the wing then it will begin to resonate. The resonance will amplify the flutter and may well lead to failure of the structure. Flutter must not occur within the normal flight operating envelope of the aircraft. Flutter can be prevented by mass balancing control surfaces to alter the moment of inertia of the surface and therefore the period of vibration (move the control surface C of G from behind the hinge to closer to the hinge). Poorly maintained aircraft, particularly those with excessive control surface backlash (play) or flexibility may mean that flutter could occur at speeds below the limit airspeed.

content.question: Aeroplanes designed for long distances cannot simply be used for short haul flights at higher frequencies, this is due to the fact that…

options.A: The procedures and checklists for this kind of aeroplanes will take too much time.
options.B: The lifetime of the fatigue sensitive parts has been based on a determined load spectrum.
options.C: Long haul aeroplanes often consume too much fuel on short haul flights.
options.D: In that case some fuel tanks remain empty during the whole flight, which stresses the aeroplane's structure in an unacceptable way.

key_points: Aircraft are specifically designed to operate routes of a certain duration, so the plane that you will be flying on will typically be a plane designed to fly that type of route
Most aircraft life times are measured in cycles and the aircraft lifespan is established by the manufacturer, usually based on take-off and landing cycles
The fuselage is most susceptible to fatigue, but the wings are too, especially on short hauls where an aircraft goes through pressurization cycles every day
learning.explanation: Aircraft are specifically designed to operate routes of a certain duration, so the plane that you will be flying on will typically be a plane designed to fly that type of route. Most aircraft life times are measured in cycles and the aircraft lifespan is established by the manufacturer, usually based on take-off and landing cycles. The fuselage is most susceptible to fatigue, but the wings are too, especially on short hauls where an aircraft goes through pressurization cycles every day. Aircraft used on longer flights experience fewer pressurization cycles, and can generally last longer. Aircrafts designed for long-haul flights typically are designed for flight cycles involving long cruises, between take-off/landing. Meaning that, for instance, the lifetime for such aircraft may be established as 50 000 flight hours but only 8000 cycles, whichever comes first => It is not economically beneficial to use long haul aircrafts on flights which are shorter than 6 h.

Select the correct/incorrect statements regarding cockpit windows:
1. On some aeroplanes the cockpit windows have an additional speed restriction, related to bird impact, when window heating is inoperative
2. Cockpit side windows are usually defogged only

options.B: 1. correct, 2. incorrect

key_points: Since pressurisation forces are to be resisted by flight deck windows as well as the cabin structure, the windows need to be strong
To achieve this, flight deck windows are constructed from several layers

learning.explanation: Since pressurisation forces are to be resisted by flight deck windows as well as the cabin structure, the windows need to be strong. To achieve this, flight deck windows are constructed from several layers. A heating element is added to the tough outer glass. There are two main benefits of heating: The first is icing resistance due to the increased temperature of the surface. Windshield heat controllers are generally capable of handling two primary functions: de-fog and de-ice. Cockpit side windows often do not feature window heating but are only equipped with defogging devices. The second is that the heated glass stays in a temperature range where it is less rigid. Window heating ensures the screen vinyl layer is kept elastic and resilient and better to absorb damage in case of a bird strike/hail. For this reason most, if not all, commercial aircraft with heated windshields will have a speed restriction below 10 000 ft if the windshield heat is inoperative, commonly not above 250 KIAS below 10 000 ft.

content.question: When is a wing not subject to any tension or compression forces?

options.B: when the aircraft is still brand new at the factory.
options.C: when the aircraft is flying at 1 g.
options.D: never, the wings are always subject to various forces.

key_points: A wing is constantly subject to various forces; tension and compression are the main ones, but wings also experience torsion and shearing forces in some cases
When a aircraft is stationary on the ground, the wing is heavy, and is being pulled down due to gravity, wanting to droop downwards away from the fixed wing root
This means that the top surface of the wing will be under tension, as it is trying to be stretched, but the bottom surface would be under compression, as it is being squashed
learning.explanation: A wing is constantly subject to various forces; tension and compression are the main ones, but wings also experience torsion and shearing forces in some cases. When a aircraft is stationary on the ground, the wing is heavy, and is being pulled down due to gravity, wanting to droop downwards away from the fixed wing root. This means that the top surface of the wing will be under tension, as it is trying to be stretched, but the bottom surface would be under compression, as it is being squashed. This effect is increased with any increased weight of the wing, engines fitted or fuel inside the wings. The effect is reversed when flying in straight and level (1g) flight, where the wings are supending the heavy fuselage due to their ability to create lift. In this case the wings are flexing upwards away from the wing root, as can be seen very clearly on newer aircraft such as the B787 and A350. In this scenario, the upper surface of the wing is being squashed, so is under compression, where the bottom surface of the wing is under tension. This effect is increased when the lift increases (larger all-up weight, higher load factor, etc.) and also when the fuel in the wings is less, and there would be less weight resistance to the upwards flexing effect. The wing flex of different scenarios can be seen in the annex depicting a B52.

content.question:
Which of the following can a pilot do to reduce the risk of overloading the airframe?
1. Avoid headwinds
2. Avoid large bank angles
3. Avoid turbulence
4. Fly below VA
5. Avoid tailwinds

key_points: An airframe is the combination of the whole structure of an aircraft
It undergoes many forces during flight, the largest being the lifting force from the wings
Whatever the weight of the aircraft, the wings have to be able to suspend that amount of force with lift, and the vast majority of that force goes through the two wing roots
learning.explanation: An airframe is the combination of the whole structure of an aircraft. It undergoes many forces during flight, the largest being the lifting force from the wings. Whatever the weight of the aircraft, the wings have to be able to suspend that amount of force with lift, and the vast majority of that force goes through the two wing roots. Hence, they are usually the strongest place on the entire aircraft. A very high stress scenario for the aircraft is pulling any sort of G-force, which requires increasing the load factor of the wings, and that means the lift of the wing has to increase. Large transport aircraft (CS-25) have a "limit load factor" of 2.5 G, and must be able to pull 150% of this (3.75 G) before complete structural failure occurs. This means that an aircraft will have to show during testing that the structure (mostly the wing spar and wing root) can withstand a lifting force of 3.75 times its own maximum take-off weight, which can be an incredible amount of force, before failing. Any G-force over the limit load factor is an "overload". An aircraft increases its loading during manoeuvres, so in banked turns (the greater the bank, the higher the wing loading), and any abrupt changes in direction, pitch, etc. Also, the loading increases in turbulence and any windshear. Aircraft stress obviously increases with weight, but the limiting load factor is set for the MTOW, so it can only get better as the aircraft gets lighter. VA is the manoeuvring speed, and if flying below VA, the aircraft will be unable to pull its limit load factor during a manoeuvre, as it will stall first, and therefore will not overload the airframe. Headwinds and tailwinds do not affect loading, as the aircraft just flies through the air mass it is in, and the head/tailwinds simply move the air mass forwards or backwards, increasing or decreasing groundspeed. As long as the winds do not change rapidly (windshear), this should not affect aircraft loading.

learning.explanation: Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is the maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane with no usable fuel. The MZFM is a structural limit based on the bending moments of the wing root. All extra weight above the MZFM must comprise fuel only. The added fuel, which is invariably carried in the wing increases its stiffness and reduces its bending and torsion (twisting). Fuel being stored in the wings is a useful feature, as the weight of the fuel counteracts the lift generated and gives relief to the roots of the cantilever wing. However, with no fuel, the wings are light, and the fuselage is heavy, which causes a large moment at the root of the wing. Therefore, the maximum zero-fuel weight implies a protection to the wing root against being overstressed. As long as it is not exceeded, lack of large amounts of fuel in the wings will not cause failure at the wing roots because of bending.

content.question: What is the purpose of floor vents in pressurised aircraft?

options.A: To provide fresh air to the cockpit and cabin.
options.B: Prevent floor distortion in the event of a rapid decompression.
options.C: To assist in equalising cabin pressure during pressurisation.
options.D: To remove unwanted smells from the toilets, etc.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.04.01.13: Explain the function of floor venting (blow-out panels). Floor vents (blow-out panels) exist in an aircraft to provide a location for easy flow of air in the event of a depressurisation between the cargo hold and the passenger cabin. If a rapid depressurisation event occurred from a hole in the cargo hold, then the high pressure in the passenger cabin would push down very strongly on the floor, causing it to buckle. If the hole was in the passenger cabin, then the cargo hold high pressure would push up on the floor, again causing it to buckle. The floor vents are panels in and around the floor that easily break/open, leaving a gap where the air can equalise pressure without further damage.

content.question: Which of the following actions can be taken to reduce the chance of a tail strike during take-off?

options.B: Accurately calculate take-off performance data.
options.D: Maintain a steep take-off angle after rotation.

key_points: Ensuring accurate calculation of take-off performance data is crucial for reducing the chance of a tail strike during take-off
Knowing the correct rotation speed allows pilots to smoothly lift the aircraft's nose at the right moment
If the rotation speed is too high, it can lead to an excessively steep climb angle, increasing the likelihood of a tail strike as the aircraft leaves the ground
learning.explanation: Ensuring accurate calculation of take-off performance data is crucial for reducing the chance of a tail strike during take-off. Knowing the correct rotation speed allows pilots to smoothly lift the aircraft's nose at the right moment. If the rotation speed is too high, it can lead to an excessively steep climb angle, increasing the likelihood of a tail strike as the aircraft leaves the ground. Conversely, if the rotation speed is too low, the aircraft may not achieve the desired pitch attitude for liftoff, potentially causing a tail strike as well. The two major threats for tail strikes to occur are during the landing flare/touchdown and during rotation on take-off. As many large jet transport aircraft are extended in length for larger passenger numbers, the long tail leaves very little tail margin during rotation, and factors such as crosswinds, gusty head/tailwinds and different weight and CG locations can lead to the potential for reduced tail clearance or tail strike. To mitigate this risk, pilots can choose to rotate at a slightly higher speed, if, for instance, they feel a gust just before rotation that might reduce their airspeed significantly. A higher airspeed means more airflow over the wings and therefore the aircraft will lift-off at a lower pitch angle, and the tail will therefore be further clear of the ground before reaching the tail strike angle. The pilot could also reduce the rate of rotation to further reduce the chance of tail strikes occurring (as might be done in an engine failure after V1 scenario), but this is not usually recommended in normal operation, and remember that both of these measures are not accounted for in the take-off performance calculation, so be careful not to run out of runway.

content.question: Which material has a high strength to weight ratio, but is the most susceptible to corrosion?

key_points: The choice of material is a very important consideration when designing an aircraft
Materials all have different properties, such as their strength, elasticity, resistance to corrosion, weight, cost, heat resistance, etc
The material that is chosen for the vast majority of aircraft construction is usually metal (composites are becoming more widely used in the sector, but metal is still the bulk of the industry)
learning.explanation: The choice of material is a very important consideration when designing an aircraft. Materials all have different properties, such as their strength, elasticity, resistance to corrosion, weight, cost, heat resistance, etc. The material that is chosen for the vast majority of aircraft construction is usually metal (composites are becoming more widely used in the sector, but metal is still the bulk of the industry). Different metals have different levels of strength, they are different to work with, and are used in different sections of the aircraft. For instance, the fuselage is usually made from an easily manufactured aluminium alloy, but sections of the hot engine are made from the very expensive, but incredibly heat resistant titanium. Alloys are a clever way of combining the different properties of two or more metals to make them better for the required usage. Now to answer this question. In general, metal has a high strength to weight ratio (in that it is strong but also light). The only better type of material for strength to weight ratio is composites. Composites such as carbon fibre, aramid (Kevlar), fibreglass, and plastic composites can be made incredibly strong, but far lighter than metals. Their fibres can also be aligned to create strength in particular directions, which is much harder to do in metal. The answer is not composites though, because they are very resistant to corrosion. Metal, however, is highly susceptible to corrosion, and it is a large part of what engineers check for and treat when they maintain an aircraft.

learning.explanation: Since pressurisation forces are to be resisted by flight deck windows as well as the cabin structure, the windows need to be very strong. To achieve this, flight deck windows are constructed from several layers. Heating elements are added to the tough outer glass. There are two main benefits of heating: The first is icing resistance due to the increased temperature of the surface. Windshield heat controllers are generally capable of handling two primary functions: de-fog and de-ice. Cockpit side windows often do not feature window heating but are only equipped with defogging devices. The second is that the heated glass stays in a temperature range where it is less rigid. The heating elements usually heat the windows into this temperature range, switch off so they do not overheat, then switch back on again if the window is going to cool down too much, cycling like this throughout every flight. Window heating ensures the screen vinyl layer is kept elastic and resilient and better to absorb damage in case of a bird strike/hail. For this reason most, if not all, commercial aircraft with heated windshields will have a speed restriction below 10 000 ft if the windshield heat is inoperative, commonly that restriction is to be not above 250 KIAS below 10 000 ft.

learning.explanation: Rivets are a commonly used method of attaching two materials together, often used to attach the skin of an airframe together. Hard landings and high manoeuvring loads can remove rivets, screws, and other fasteners through shearing forces, for example, if the "improper maintenance or installation" option is not present in the exam, this option should be chosen. content.question: Which of the following correctly describes the construction of flight deck windshields for commercial jet aircraft?

options.A: A single sheet of toughened glass, to give the pilots the best view outwards.
options.B: Flexible vinyl only, to withstand high differential pressures.
options.C: Two or three layers separated by air, to insulate the cockpit at high altitudes.
options.D: Layers of toughened glass and vinyl, to aid impact resistance from bird strike.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.04.01.09: Explain why flight-deck windows are constructed with different layers. The flight deck windshield is made of many different layers of materials, mostly plastics such as acrylic and vinyl, to give it favourable properties such as high strength, good flexibility (for impact resistance) and a hard wearing outer coating, with good rain resistance. They also sometimes contain layers of toughened (tempered) glass, as it is incredibly strong, and protects well against small impacts at high speed. The layering of different materials help to provide better impact resistance than one type of material only, combining the best features of all the materials. Aircraft windshields also contain heating elements which have a couple of different jobs, their main job being to keep the plastics (vinyl and acrylic) in a slightly softer state, where they are flexible enough to absorb and deflect impacts from objects like birds at very high speeds. If the heating was not present, then the windshield would become very brittle in the extreme cold of the upper airways and could break more easily upon impact.

content.question: An operator notices corrosion on some metal parts of their aircraft fleet. What actions should they take?

options.A: Wash the aeroplanes thoroughly after each flight.
options.B: Replace the metal parts affected by corrosion with plastic or composite materials where possible.
options.C: Repair, prime and paint the damaged parts.
options.D: Paint over the corrosion to protect the area and add strength.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.02.01.02: State the advantages and disadvantages of composite materials compared with metal alloys by considering the following: strength-to-weight ratio; capability to tailor the strength to the direction of the load; stiffness; electrical conductivity (lightning); resistance to fatigue and corrosion; resistance to cost; discovering damage during a pre-flight inspection. The appropriate action to take if an operator notices corrosion on metal parts of their aircraft fleet is to repair, prime, and paint the damaged parts. This is important because corrosion can weaken the metal and compromise the structural integrity of the aircraft, which can be a safety hazard. Replacing the metal parts with plastic or composite materials may be an option, but it can be expensive and may not always be feasible. It is also important to note that different materials have different properties, and they may not be suitable for all applications. Washing the aircraft thoroughly after each flight may be important for general maintenance but may not prevent corrosion. A notable point is that washing the aircraft after every flight could cause some water based corrosion or rusting over time, so is not a good idea to fight corrosion. Painting over the corrosion to protect the area and add strength is not a recommended practice as it does not address the underlying corrosion issue and can lead to further damage. Therefore, the best course of action is to have the affected parts assessed by a qualified technician and have the corrosion removed and repaired, and then properly primed and painted to protect against further corrosion.

content.question: Which of the following statements is true about "plug type" aircraft doors?

options.A: They are always used in unpressurised aircraft.
options.B: Each door can move inside and outside the aircraft.
options.C: They must have a pressure relief valve.
options.D: They can only be hydraulically or electrically operated.

key_points: On pressurised aircraft, the pressure hull has to be made very strong to withstand the constant "bulging" force of the high pressure air inside
There are many potential weak points in this, including windows, hatches, and doors
Therefore, the doors in a pressurised aeroplane have to be specifically designed to seal to the frame and not break or buckle under the forces of pressurisation
learning.explanation: On pressurised aircraft, the pressure hull has to be made very strong to withstand the constant "bulging" force of the high pressure air inside. There are many potential weak points in this, including windows, hatches, and doors. Therefore, the doors in a pressurised aeroplane have to be specifically designed to seal to the frame and not break or buckle under the forces of pressurisation. This is why pressurised aircraft often use "plug type" doors, where the door is larger than the frame, and is mounted inside of the frame, so the door is being pushed into the door frame by the force of air pressure, acting like a "plug" for the hole. These doors have to be opened inwards into the aircraft, and then are usually hinged in such a way that they can go back through the door frame sideways and remain outside the aircraft whilst open. This is done primarily to reduce the space taken up inside the aircraft by the door, which also helps during an evacuation. Therefore, the most correct answer is that the door can move inside and outside the aircraft. As for the other options; They are not always used in unpressurised aircraft, in fact I imagine that is quite rare. They do not need a pressure relief valve, they are supposed to hold quite high pressure loads, and there will be an over-pressure relief valve somewhere on the aircraft fuselage. They can be manually operated, and often are.

content.question: The heating facility for the windshield of an aircraft is…

options.A: Used on a continual basis as it reduces the thermal gradients which adversely affect the useful life of the components.
options.B: Harmful to the integrity of the windows in the event of a bird strike.
options.C: Used only at low altitudes where there is a risk of ice formation.
options.D: Only used when hot air demisting is insufficient.

learning.explanation: 021.02.04.01.10: Explain the function of window heating for structural purposes. The flight deck windshield is made of many different layers of materials, mostly plastics such as acrylic and vinyl, as well as some layers of toughened glass, to give it favourable properties such as high strength, good flexibility (for impact resistance) and a hard wearing outer coating, with good rain resistance. They also contain heating elements which have a couple of different jobs, their main job being to keep the plastics in a slightly softer state, where they are flexible enough to absorb and deflect impacts from objects like birds at very high speeds (it is therefore used on a continuous basis during the entire flight). If the heating was not present, then the windshield would become very brittle in the extreme cold of the upper airways and could break more easily upon impact. The secondary jobs of the heated windshield are de-fogging and de-icing, which are important in their own right, but are certainly a secondary consideration to the impact resistance. Another rationale for the constant operation of the window heating system is the mitigation of thermal gradients. When the window heating system is activated, it ensures that the window pane remains at a consistent temperature throughout the entirety of the flight.

content.question: Regarding the load factor, an aircraft's maximum allowable load factor is determined by the manufacturer. For a particular aircraft, the maximum load limit with flaps extended is half of the load factor in the clean configuration. Which of the following options completes the statement correctly? In level and unaccelerated flight...

options.A: the difference between maximum load limit for flaps extended and clean wing is necessary as structural strength of the wing is lower with flaps extended.
options.B: the load factor with flaps extended will be higher than the load factor in the clean configuration.
options.C: the margin between actual load factor and maximum load factor decreases with increased bank angle.
options.D: the load factor at which structural damage occurs can never be more than +2.0G when flaps are extended.

key_points: Let's go through each answer: "In level and unaccelerated flight
the difference between maximum load limit for flaps extended and clean wing is necessary as structural strength of the wing is lower with flaps extended
" This is saying that the wing is weaker when flaps are extended
learning.explanation: Let's go through each answer: "In level and unaccelerated flight. the difference between maximum load limit for flaps extended and clean wing is necessary as structural strength of the wing is lower with flaps extended." This is saying that the wing is weaker when flaps are extended. This is not correct, as the wing structure does not rely of the flaps. What actually causes the lower maximum load factor with flaps extended is the flap mechanism. With flaps extended, the higher the load factor, the more force is travelling through the mechanism which locks the flaps down, which are moving parts, so not as strong as the wing itself. "In level and unaccelerated flight. the load factor with flaps extended will be higher than the load factor in the clean configuration." The load factor is simply lift/weight, and in straight and level flight, the lift will always equal the weight, therefore the load factor is 1, whether the flaps are up and down. It has not specified straight flight, but the same would be true in a turn of a particular bank angle; load factor is the same, with or without flaps. "In level and unaccelerated flight. the margin between current load factor and maximum load factor decreases with increased bank angle." Correct. In a level turn, the aircraft's wings have to produce a higher lift force, as the lift force is no longer straight upwards, but is instead pointing into the direction of turn somewhat. The steeper the bank angle, the greater the lift force has to be (to remain level), which means that the actual load factor has to increase. As the maximum load factor is a fixed value, the margin between actual and maximum decreases with increased bank angle. "In level and unaccelerated flight. the load factor at which structural damage occurs can never be more than +2.0G when flaps are extended." We had no feedback for this option, so made this up to fill in the gap. It is incorrect because flaps can be made as strong as you like. They could manage up to +15G if the manufacturer wants to. There are minimum values to their strength though, defined in the certification specifications.

content.question: Which statement describes how forces act on the airframe during manoeuvring in flight?

options.A: Both strain and stress increase as the forces increase.
options.B: When the lift exactly opposes the weight, strain is NOT increased due to stress.
options.C: Both stress and strain decrease as the forces increase.
options.D: The strain increases and stress decreases as the forces increase.

key_points: An aircraft is constantly subject to various forces; tension, compression, torsion and shearing forces are all occurring in an aircraft in varying amounts
Any of these forces can be described in terms of stress and strain
Stress is the measure of force applied (per unit of cross-sectional area) whereas strain is the measure of deformation, usually as a proportion of the original size of the component
learning.explanation: An aircraft is constantly subject to various forces; tension, compression, torsion and shearing forces are all occurring in an aircraft in varying amounts. Any of these forces can be described in terms of stress and strain. Stress is the measure of force applied (per unit of cross-sectional area) whereas strain is the measure of deformation, usually as a proportion of the original size of the component. They are present on almost every item in some way, and are present in a multitude of different ways on an aircraft at all times. When an aircraft manoeuvres, for instance by entering a turn, the load factor on the wings increases, as the wings are now required to produce more lift than before. This leads to a change in the stress (and therefore strain) on the aircraft, in particular for this scenario, an increased load on the wing spars and roots, which cause a flex in the wing, demonstrating the extra strain present. Therefore, for this question, any force increase will increase the stress on the aircraft (as stress is force per unit area) and any stress will increase strain (the aircraft's deformation due to the stress).

content.question: When are stress and strain zero in an aircraft structure?

options.A: When the aircraft has zero flight hours.
options.B: When parked, with the engines not running.
options.C: When flying with a 1G load factor.
options.D: Never, stress and strain are always present.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.01.02.01.01: Explain how stress and strain are always present in an aircraft structure both when parked and during manoeuvring. Remark: Stress is the internal force per unit area inside a structural part as a result of external loads. Strain is the deformation caused by the action of stress on a material. An aircraft is constantly subject to various forces; tension, compression, torsion and shearing forces are all occurring in an aircraft in varying amounts. For instance, when stationary on the ground, the wing is heavy, and is being pulled down due to gravity, wanting to droop downwards away from the fixed wing root. This means that the top surface of the wing will be under tension, as it is trying to be stretched, but the bottom surface would be under compression, as it is being squashed. Also, The weight of the whole aircraft is being opposed by reaction forces that travel through the landing gear and all the structurally load bearing components of the structure. These are amongst the many forces acting on a stationary aeroplane. The forces are very different when flying in straight and level (1 G) flight, where, for instance, the wings are suspending the heavy fuselage due to their ability to create lift. In this case the wings are flexing upwards away from the wing root, as can be seen very clearly on newer aircraft such as the B787 and A350. In this scenario, the upper surface of the wing is being squashed, so is under compression, where the bottom surface of the wing is under tension. The rest of the aircraft also sustains new forces, such as that of pressurisation on the pressure hull. The forces change again during manoeuvres, taxi, take-off and landing. Any of these forces can be described in terms of stress and strain. Stress is the measure of force applied (per unit of cross-sectional area) whereas strain is the measure of deformation, usually as a proportion of the original size of the component. They are present on almost every item in some way, and are present in a multitude of different ways on an aircraft at all times.

Temperature - an increase in temperature will generally cause an increase in the corrosion rate. A rule of thumb is that temperature increases of 10°C will double the corrosion rate. Humidity - has a direct effect on the rate of corrosion of metals. The higher the humidity, the higher the rate of corrosion. Rainfall - leads to an increased humidity - therefore, higher rate of corrosion. Sulphur Dioxide (pollution) - is known to cause considerable damage to materials. These pollutants can accelerate the rate of corrosion. Air Salinity - an increase in air salinity levels will generally cause an increase in the corrosion rate. Over the ocean at low altitude, the air will have a high salinity, leading to a build up of salt on the airframe, which, when mixed with water, can lead to fast corrosion of metal. The best way to deal with the operator's problem would be to wash the aircraft as often as they can, and very thoroughly, to clear off the salt and replace it with clean water that corrodes metal much less. The correct option (rightly) mentions the engine too, as this can build up salt deposits in just the same way as the airframe does, and corrosion is obviously much more dangerous when there are pieces of metal spinning at 50 000 RPM. Whilst the best long term fix for this issue would be changing the fleet of aircraft to ones more suited to the task, this would be immensely expensive, and maybe not even possible. Yes, if you were doing some light aircraft intelligence, surveillance or reconnaissance work, then you could change to a fleet of composite aircraft to remove the risk of corrosion, which is a huge investment, but there are aircraft available for that type of operation, so is possible. However, if you were doing oil spill response or something which requires large jets, they are all metal and all subject to corrosion (except some of the newer jets like B787 and A350), so this answer is not feasible.

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.01.02.01.02: Describe the following types of loads that an aircraft may be subjected to, when they occur, and how a pilot may affect their magnitude: static loads; dynamic loads; cyclic loads. As stated in the Learning Objective above, there are three types of load, but they are not completely mutually exclusive. Static loads are loads that do not change in size, position or direction. These could be loads such as the weight of the aircraft through the wheels when parked, or the tension on the upper skin of the wing when on the ground. They are quite easy to account for. Dynamic loads are loads that do change in size, position or direction. They must be accounted for more heavily by engineers, as a constantly changing load can cause more fatigue or early failure if not expected. There are countless dynamic loads on an aircraft, taxiing loads, the engine pylons, the bending of the wing spar in turbulent flight, the control surfaces during manoeuvring, etc. Cyclic loads are a special type of the aforementioned loads. They are loads which have expected cycles, the main one being the pressurisation cycle of the aircraft. It is a static load when non-pressurised and when fully pressurised, but dynamic as it changes. The cyclical nature does mean that engineers can build it to last, and monitor it's progress also, giving an aircraft a number of available pressurisation cycles, which can dictate its lifespan. This question simply wants you to know that there are constantly loads of all types occuring on an aircraft at all times. static loads also occur whilst in flight, and dynamic loads occur on the ground, even when parked (wind, boarding, etc.), so the two statements are both incorrect.

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.01.01.01.02: Explain the purpose of redundancy in aircraft design. Redundancy is another word for additional, or duplicate, and means that there is not just one load path or one source for any system. Essentially, to provide the correct amount of safety in the case of a failure under the "fail-safe" design concept, there needs to be another option to stop a catastrophic event occurring. For structural items, this is usually multiple load paths, so that if one breaks, the other can take the required forces without fully breaking. For systems, there are usually extra sources (electrical power, hydraulic pressure, etc.) to stop a complete failure of the more essential systems, such as flight controls or landing gear extension.

learning.explanation: Note: This should be a principles of flight question really, as per the learning objectives, but it has been reported mutiple times in AGK. The limit load (usually known as limit load factor) of an aeroplane is the maximum load it is expected to experience during flight operations. The aircraft must be capable of withstanding 150% of this "limit load" before failure occurs (which is the "ultimate load"). CS-25 aircraft, for instance, have a limit load factor of 2.5G at the minimum, meaning that they must be tested to 3.75G (150% of 2.5) without failure. Any forces higher than 2.5G can begin to cause irreversible bending of the airframe and are not assured to be withstood by every airframe in a fleet, so it is never recommended to exceed this limit load factor unless extreme circumstances make it necessary for safety.

learning.explanation: Corrosion is where two substances begin to change the composition of each other when mixed.
